clinical_study.brief_title: Urdu Version of Neck Pain and Disability Scale (NPAD)
clinical_study.official_title: Reliability and Validity of Urdu Version of Neck Pain and Disability Scale (NPAD)

brief_summary.textblock: In this study, the examiners will investigate the reliability and validity of neck pain and disability scale in Urdu language in Pakistani patients with neck pain and related disability.

detailed_description.textblock:
The objective of this study is to translate as well as culturally adapt the neck pain and disability scale (NPAD) into Urdu language and to test its reliability and validity in patients with neck pain in Pakistan. This cross-sectional survey will use convenience sampling technique to enroll the participants on a pre-defined criteria.
The outcomes of this study will help in finding the reliability and validity of NPAD in patients with neck pain and associated disability. The reliability of this scale will be examined using internal consistency and test-retest methods. The internal consistency will be checked by Cronbach's alpha value. The test-retest reliability will be analyzed using an interclass correlation with 100 patients.

primary_outcome.description: NPAD scale is a multidimensional configuration measure which includes a 20-item questionnaire that helps in the evaluating the intensity of pain and disability of neck. This scale is intended to measure the mobility and severity issues of neck and the influence of traumas related to neck in obstruction of daily activities. This is a very simple tool, designed using VAS and is easy to fill out by the patients and is used for most of the assessments involving neck discomforts.It measures the impact of discomfort due to pain on all cultural, interpersonal, practical and professional areas of life as well as on emotions.

secondary_outcome.description: This assessment tool is used to evaluate the quality of various functional activities of daily life. This questionnaire consists of 10 sub-items in total, including the pain, lifting, personal care, work activities, headaches, sleep, drive and recreational activities. Apiece item is scored along the range from 0-5.NDI is a one-dimensional assessment tool is deliberated to provide us with information about how the neck discomfort influences the activities and the capacity to function. NDI has sufficient dependability and pertinence to maintain its spot as a mostly used self-declared estimation tool for neck disorders. This scale (NDI) can be managed to evaluate the patient's present state and their advancement during the treatment.

The PDI is an authentic simple measure of indiscriminate pain and disability and is used for the evaluation of the influence of pain on the capability of an individual's participation skills in everyday important activities. It has also been used in assessment of the patients before interventions and then monitoring them over time to evaluate the efficacy of interventions. This scale comprises of 7 sections which include family, home responsibilities, recreation, occupation, sexual and social activities, self-care and life support and these items are totaled into a score between 0-70.

VAS is an authentic, idiosyncratic assessment tool with a horizontal line used for evaluation of chronic and acute pain and perception of pain level. It measures the characteristic of pain and comprises a spectrum with scores that helps in the assessment of frequency and the intensity of the pain experienced by the individual. The patient picks out a point on the line that best describes their apprehension of pain.

study_pop.textblock: People with non-specific chronic neck pain that interferes with their social, recreational, functional, vocational and emotional aspects of living. Chronic non-specific neck pain is related to limited cervical mobility, impaired function, neck muscles myofascial pain syndrome, and stress at work. The aforementioned factors are strongly related and may lead to a negative impact on health-related quality of life.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria
- Individuals including both male and females between age 18 and 65 years.
- Participants with non-specific chronic pain of neck (>3 months in duration).
- Individuals with sufficient knowledge and understanding of Urdu language.
Exclusion Criteria
- Individuals with history of cervical surgery.
- Individuals with cervical myelopathy or radiculopathy, regional tumors, disc herniation, vertebral fractures, traumatic injuries, cardiovascular and pulmonary diseases, pregnancy or any behavioral problems were excluded
- Individuals with any pertinent comorbidities including heart attack, cancer, cognitive impairment or infection were also excluded. herniation, vertebral fractures, traumatic injuries, cardiovascular and pulmonary diseases, pregnancy or any behavioral problems were excluded
